channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ratko Mladic Is Convicted in 1990s Slaughter of Bosnian Muslims
item.media:description: Ratko Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb general, entering the courtroom in The Hague on Wednesday to hear the verdict from the United Nations war crimes tribunal.
item.description: A U.N. war crimes tribunal gave the Bosnian Serb former general a life sentence for his role in one of the worst atrocities in 20th-century Europe.
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia

item.title: Robert Mugabe Resigns as Zimbabwe’s President, Ending 37-Year Rule
item.media:description: Zimbabweans celebrated Mr. Mugabe’s resignation outside the Parliament in Harare.
item.description: It seemed to be an abrupt capitulation by Mr. Mugabe, who had refused only two days earlier to step down.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI and JEFFREY MOYO
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Merkel’s Troubles May Spell Trouble for All of Europe
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany speaking with Social Democratic members during a session of the Bundestag in Berlin on Tuesday.
item.description: The German leader’s failure to form a coalition government is a blow to hopes for a strong Franco-German engine to drive European Union reform.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: After a Mysterious Odyssey, Lebanon’s Prime Minister Is Home
item.media:description: Prime Minister Saad Hariri of Lebanon prayed at the grave of his father on Tuesday night after returning to Beirut. He did not answer questions about his mysterious two-week absence from Lebanon.
item.description: Many questions remain, including whether he will make his resignation official or rescind it, and whether Saudi Arabia had pressed him to resign.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Navy Aircraft With 11 Aboard Crashes Into Waters Off Japan
item.media:description: The aircraft carrier Ronald Reagan during recent exercises in the Philippine Sea. A U.S. Navy aircraft was on its way to the carrier when it crashed off Okinawa on Wednesday, the Seventh Fleet said.
item.description: Eight people were rescued and a search was underway for the other three, the Navy’s Seventh Fleet said. It was the fleet’s fifth accident this year.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Nigeria Mosque Targeted in Deadly Suicide Bombing
item.media:description: A still taken from television showing the interior of a mosque in Mubi, Nigeria, after a deadly attack by a suicide bomber on Tuesday.
item.description: The authorities blamed Boko Haram for the attack, which targeted worshipers at morning prayers. One official said at least 50 people had been killed.
item.dc:creator: EMMANUEL AKINWOTU and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Restoring North Korea to Terrorism Blacklist Dims Hopes for Talks
item.media:description: The central rail station in Pyongyang, North Korea, this month. President Trump has designated North Korea as a state sponsor of terrorism, reversing a move by the second Bush administration.
item.description: Analysts say the North may use the American move as an excuse for more weapons tests.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Assad and Putin Meet, as Russia Pushes to End Syrian War
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, left, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met in Sochi, Russia, on Monday.
item.description: Russian officials have said they want the Syrian leader’s support for political reform, but doubts remain about how much Moscow was willing or able to push.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Damascus Journal: They Stayed Put, but Their City Disappeared
item.media:description: A poster in Damascus, Syria, depicting President Bashar al-Assad.
item.description: In Syria’s capital, those who remain wonder why they’re still there when so many friends have packed up, died or vanished.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Losing London: Where Brexit Hurts: The Nurses and Doctors Leaving London
item.media:description: The liver unit at King’s College Hospital in southeast London is world famous and has a very European staff. “The English are in the minority,” according to Dr. Georg Auzinger, the clinical head of critical care.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Britain’s treasured health care system was used as rallying cry by anti-E.U. campaigners. Many of its European staff now feel betrayed. Thousands have quit.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Dramatic Video of North Korea Defector’s Getaway Under Fire
item.description: Footage of the actual escape by a North Korean soldier into South Korea, as seen from South Korean side.

item.title: North Korean Troops Violated Truce While Chasing Defector, U.N. Command Says
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: a North Korean defector running from a jeep on Nov. 13; a North Korean soldier shooting at the defector in the Joint Security Area of the demilitarized zone; a North Korea soldier running back to the north side of the Joint Security Area; the defector on the ground after being shot.
item.description: The United Nations Command accused North Korean troops of violating the armistice by firing weapons and crossing the border to chase a defector.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: As Malaria Resists Treatment, Experts Warn of Global Crisis
item.media:description: Tra Thi Nhan owns a pharmacy in Bu Gia Map, Vietnam, in a forested area near the Cambodian border. She attributed the district’s persistent malaria problem to “our topography.”
item.media:credit: Quinn Ryan Mattingly for The New York Times
item.description: A strain of malaria resistant to two drugs, including artemisinin, which was once seen as a miracle cure, is spreading, and experts fear that it could reach Africa.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES and DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: A Dictator’s Playbook: How Mugabe Clung to Power
item.description: After nearly four decades in power, Zimbabwe's ruler, Robert Mugabe, resigned in the wake of a military takeover. How did the notorious strongman manage to keep his opponents at bay for so long?

item.title: Prosecutor and Judge Issue Rare Response to Criticism From Turkey
item.media:description: Reza Zarrab, the Turkish gold trader whose criminal case has attracted high-powered lawyers and worldwide interest, in 2013.
item.description: The criminal case of Reza Zarrab, a Turkish gold trader, has been called a plot against the Turkish Republic by its president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: U.S. Agency Foresees Severe Famine in Yemen Under Saudi Blockade
item.media:description: Yemenis waiting to collect drinking water in Sana, Yemen. A Saudi-led blockade has threatened to choke off Yemen’s freshwater supply.
item.description: The Famine Early Warning Systems Network added its voice to the alarms of imminent and widespread famine in Yemen because of the Saudi-led blockade.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Net Neutrality, John Conyers, Zimbabwe: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: China’s Flashy Ex-Internet Censor Faces Corruption Investigation
item.media:description: China’s former top internet regulator, Lu Wei, is being investigated by the Communist Party’s anti-corruption arm.
item.description: The onetime gatekeeper of China’s internet, who purged China’s social media of its most beloved personalities, has been detained and is under investigation.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and PAUL MOZUR
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)

item.title: Greece, Looking to Move Past Bailouts, Unveils Ambitious Budget
item.description: The country is trying to wean itself off the international assistance that it has relied on in recent years, and is projecting strong economic growth for next year.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: U.S. Bribery Case Sheds Light on Mysterious Chinese Company
item.media:description: President Milos Zeman of the Czech Republic, right, in Shanghai in September 2015 for the signing of agreements between companies from his country and the Chinese conglomerate CEFC.
item.media:credit: Lucie Mikolaskova/Czech News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: A Justice Department complaint alleges that a vast private Chinese conglomerate used commercial and diplomatic channels to bribe African officials and win contracts.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Romania Gay Marriage Case Could Have Outsize Impact in Europe
item.media:description: Adrian Coman outside the Constitutional Court of Romania in Bucharest in 2016. He is pressing for the right to legal residency for his American husband.
item.description: The case addresses whether the American husband of a Romanian man should be afforded residency rights in Romania. But its impact could be felt further afield.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Victims of Canada’s ‘Gay Purge’ to Get Apology from Trudeau
item.media:description: Orde Morton was a Canadian diplomat in 1969 when he was told that he would not be promoted because he was gay.
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will apologize next week for a program that removed perhaps thousands of gays and lesbians from the public service, the military and the Mounties.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Six of Our Favorite Stories on Germany’s Politics
item.media:description: A campaign poster in Berlin for Angela Merkel, whose future as chancellor of Germany seemed all but certain after elections in September.
item.description: Some of our recent coverage of Germany and its leader, Angela Merkel, who is now facing an enormous challenge in forming a new government.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: 10 of Our Best Reads on Zimbabwe
item.media:description: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe. At 93, he is the world’s oldest head of state.
item.media:credit: Pete Muller for The New York Times
item.description: The southern African nation is at a pivotal moment after the reported resignation of Robert Mugabe as president.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Russia, in Reversal, Confirms Radiation Spike
item.media:description: A map provided by the French Institute for Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety showed levels of ruthenium 106 across Europe.
item.description: The state weather service in Moscow acknowledged “extremely high pollution” in a region close to a sprawling Soviet-era nuclear plant.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW LUXMOORE and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Germany Arrests 6 Syrian Migrants Suspected of ISIS Links
item.media:description: Anis Amri, a Tunisian who had pledged allegiance to the Islamic State, hijacked a truck and plowed through a Christmas market in Berlin last year, killing at least a dozen people.
item.description: The detentions fanned fears that extremists posing as asylum seekers were targeting Europe.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and KATARINA JOHANNSEN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: En France, la « révolte » contre le harcèlement sexuel se heurte aux résistances culturelles
item.media:description: ​Un rassemblement contre les violences sexistes et sexuelles à Paris le mois dernier.​
item.description: De nombreuses personnes en France appellent à faire du harcèlement sexuel une urgence nationale, mais des obstacles légaux et culturels découragent les femmes qui souhaitent porter plainte pour harcèlement sexuel au travail.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: China Finds Lawyer Who Exposed Torture Allegations Guilty of Inciting Subversion
item.media:description: Supporters of the disbarred lawyer Jiang Tianyong demonstrating late last year in Hong Kong.
item.description: Jiang Tianyong got a two-year term after helping bring to light another lawyer’s claims of being brutalized in custody.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Protesting Coal Mining From a Treehouse
item.description: For years, activists have been protesting the expansion of coal mining in the Hambach Forest in Germany by living in treehouses. A court ruling may soon change that.

item.title: Prosecutor’s Move in Afghan War Inquiry May Mean Clash With U.S.
item.media:description: The International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor, Fatou Bensouda, in 2015.
item.description: An International Criminal Court prosecutor requested permission to start an inquiry that could implicate members of the U.S. military and the C.I.A.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and MARLISE SIMONS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Saudi Arabia Squeezes Detainees as It Tries to Seize Assets
item.media:description: The Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, where many Saudis accused of corruption have been detained.
item.media:credit: Tasneem Alsultan for The New York Times
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s efforts to get princes and businessmen detained on corruption charges to hand over their assets have raised legal concerns abroad.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: After Mugabe, What’s Next for Zimbabweans?
item.description: Zimbabwe may have a new leader for the first time in 37 years. Now, those who grew up under Robert Mugabe share a mix of hope and skepticism about the country’s future.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: AT&T, North Korea, Angela Merkel: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: U.S. Airstrikes in Afghanistan Take Aim at Taliban Opium Labs
item.media:description: Poppy buds on the outskirts of Kandahar Province in Afghanistan. The country produces around 85 percent of the world’s opium.
item.description: The airstrikes are part of what is expected to be a sustained campaign targeting a lucrative source of funding for the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip Celebrate 70 Years of Marriage
item.media:description: The official portrait of Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip for their platinum wedding anniversary.
item.description: Britain’s longest-serving monarch and her husband noted the occasion with the release of new photographic portraits.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: ‘Nut Rage’ Whistle-Blower Says Korean Air Retaliated Against Him
item.media:description: A Korean Air jet taking off at Incheon International Airport in Incheon, South Korea, in February. The airline is being sued by a whistle-blower.
item.description: The flight attendant who exposed a Korean Air executive’s actions says he was illegally demoted and ostracized.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Workers Lured to Australia Find Low Pay and Tough Conditions
item.media:description: Gabi Cho in her home in Lidcombe, an area of Sydney, Australia. Ms. Cho has accused the hair salon she once worked at of underpaying her and exploiting her lack of English skills.
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.description: Many of the country’s more than 900,000 temporary foreign workers make less than minimum wage but feel they can’t complain, a new survey showed.
item.dc:creator: JACQUELINE WILLIAMS

item.title: Key European Agencies Move to Continent, Signs of Brexit’s Toll
item.media:description: The headquarters of the European Medicines Agency in London. The agency will move to Amsterdam as a result of Britain’s impending exit from the European Union.
item.media:credit: José Sarmento Matos for The New York Times
item.description: The relocation of the European Medicines Agency and the European Banking Authority indicate how Britain’s impending exit from the European Union could diminish its economic clout.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: U.N. Chief ‘Horrified’ by Report of Libya Slave Auction
item.media:description: Refugees in the courtyard of a United Nations refugee agency building in Niamey, Niger, on Friday, after they were evacuated from Libya.
item.description: After CNN reported that migrants had been sold at auction, Secretary General António Guterres said the acts depicted “may amount to crimes against humanity.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Wake Up and Smell the Traffic? London Tries Coffee to Power Buses
item.media:description: The first batch of coffee-based oil added to the fuel for London’s buses would be enough to run one of the vehicles for about a year.
item.description: In an effort to curb toxic diesel fumes, oil from used grounds has been added to the fuel for the British capital’s iconic red double-deckers.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: In Crisis, Angela Merkel Prefers Elections to Minority Rule
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel in Berlin on Monday. She said she remained hopeful about forming a majority government.
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel says she would prefer a new round of elections to leading a minority government, if the quest for a majority coalition fails.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY and KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Trump Returns North Korea to List of State Sponsors of Terrorism
item.description: North Korea had been removed from the list under the George W. Bush administration in an attempt to salvage negotiations for a nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Northern Ireland Is Sinking Into a ‘Profound Crisis’
item.media:description: The Northern Irish Parliament buildings, commonly known as Stormont. Its government collapsed in January.
item.description: A nearly yearlong standoff has paralyzed its institutions and is threatening a 1998 treaty that largely ended three decades of fighting.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Just as in 1980, Zimbabwe’s Celebration May Be Short-Lived
item.media:description: Robert Mugabe in Salisbury, Zimbabwe, in April 1980, the month the former British colony became an independent nation.
item.description: A veteran reporter who was in the country when Robert Mugabe first took power sees disturbing parallels with the current moment of hope and joy.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Kim Jong-un Disciplines North Korea’s Top Military Organization
item.media:description: A military parade in Pyongyang, North Korea, in April. The country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, appears to be trying to curb the influence of the military.
item.description: The move is the latest sign that the North Korean leader is trying to tighten his grip on party elites and the armed forces amid a nuclear standoff with the United States.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Paris Journal: A Brothel, Repurposed and Restored, Reveals Another Paris
item.media:description: The owner, Caroline Senot, right, and a restorer, Mathilde de Blas, checked the progress of the renovation of the former brothel Aux Belles Poules in Paris.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Hidden for decades behind crude wooden boards, an ornate ceramic frieze at the former Aux Belles Poules tells a story of the city’s once-thriving sex business.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Silent Sub: Time Is the Enemy as Argentina Hunts a Lost Vessel
item.media:description: The Comandante Espora leaving the naval base in Mar del Plata, Argentina, on Saturday as part of the search for a missing submarine.
item.description: Six days after the ARA San Juan lost contact, with hopes raised and dashed, families of its 44 crew members are growing increasingly anxious.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI and ERNESTO LONDOÑO
